quest_title: The current conduction in a discharged tube is due to
explanation_txt: Electrons emitted from cathode acquire high kinetic energy in the presence of electric field inside discharge tube. They, in turn, hit other gas atoms separating +ve ions and other extra electrons. Current in discharge tube is conducted by these +ve ions and electrons.

\(\lambda_{\min }=\cfrac{h c}{e V}\)

quest_title: Refractive index of air is 1.0003. The correct thickness of air column which will have one more wavelength of yellow light (6000 {\AA}) than in the same thickness in vacuum is
explanation_txt: For vacuum \(t=n\, \lambda _{o} \) .....(i) For air \(t=(n+1)\, \lambda _{a} \) .....(ii) From equation (i) and (ii) \[t=\cfrac{\lambda }{\mu -1} =\cfrac{6\times 10^{-7} }{1.0003-1} \left(\mu =\cfrac{\lambda _{o} }{\lambda _{a} } \right)\] \(=2\times 10^{-3} m\) = 2\(\textit{mm}\).
question_plain_title: Refractive index of air is 1.0003. The correct thickness of air column which will have one more wavelength of yellow light (6000 {\AA}) than in the same thickness in vacuum is
explanation_plain_text: For vacuum .....(i) For air .....(ii) From equation (i) and (ii) = 2.

quest_title: From top of tower a particle is projected with 20 m/s at an angle 30\({}^{o}\) with horizontal. The particle will move right angle to its initial position after
explanation_txt:
\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}}_{1} . \overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}}_{2}=0\)

\(\text { or, }(u \cos \theta \hat{i}+u \sin \theta \hat{j}) \cdot\{u \cos \theta \hat{i}+(u \sin \theta-g t) \hat{j}\}=0\)

\(\text { or, } u^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta+u \sin \theta(u \sin \theta-g t)=0 \)
\(\text { or, } u^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta=-u \sin \theta(u \sin \theta-g t) \)
\(\text { or, } 20 \cos ^{2} 30^{\circ}=-\sin 30^{\circ}\left(20 \sin 30^{\circ}-10 t\right) \)

or, \(15=-5+5 \mathrm{t}\)

\(\therefore t=\cfrac{20}{5}=4 \mathrm{sec}\)

quest_title: A proton and an \(\text{\(\alpha\)}\)-particle are situated at \(\text{r}\) distance apart. At a very large distance apart when released, the KE of proton will be
explanation_txt:
The PE between proton and \(\alpha\) -particle is

\(U=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{e(2 e)}{r}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{2 e^{2}}{r}\)

KE of proton and \(\alpha\) -particle is given by

\(\mathrm{KE}=\cfrac{P^{2}}{2 m}+\cfrac{P^{2}}{2(4 m)}=\cfrac{5}{4} \times \cfrac{P^{2}}{2 m}\)

\(\therefore\, \cfrac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0} \cfrac{2e^2}{r} = \cfrac{5}{4} \times \cfrac{P^2}{2m} \)

Or, \(\cfrac{P^{2}}{2 m}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{8 e^{2}}{5 r}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{KE}\) of proton \(=\cfrac{P^{2}}{2 m}=\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \times \cfrac{8 e^{2}}{5 r}\)

quest_title: The line \(x - 2 y = 0\) will be a bisector of the angle between the lines represented by the equation \(x ^ { 2 } - 2 h x y - 2 y ^ { 2 } = 0\), if \(h=\)
explanation_txt:
Here one equation of bisector is \(x - 2 y = 0\). We know that both bisectors are perpendicular, therefore second bisector will be \(2 x + y = 0\) because it passes through origin.

Hence the combined equations of bisectors is given by \(( 2 x + y ) ( x - 2 y ) = 0 \Rightarrow - 2 x ^ { 2 } + 3 x y + 2 y ^ { 2 } = 0\)

Now comparing it by \(h x ^ { 2 } + 3 x y - h y ^ { 2 } = 0\), we get h = –2.

quest_title: \(\begin{array} { l } { 20 \mathrm { ml } \text { of } 0.5 \mathrm { NHCl } \text { and } 35 \mathrm { ml } \text { of } 0.1 \mathrm { N } \text { NaOH are mixed.} } \\ { \text { The resulting solution will } } \end{array}\)
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array} { l } { \text { (i) } 20 \mathrm { ml } \text { of } 0.5 \mathrm { NHCl } } \\ { 0.5 \mathrm { N } \Rightarrow 1000 \mathrm { ml } 0.5 \text { mole } \mathrm { HCl } \text { is present in } 20 \mathrm { ml } } \\ { = \cfrac { 20 \times 0.5 } { 1000 } = 1.0 \times 10 ^ { - 2 } } \end{array}\)

\(\begin{array} { l } { \text { (ii) } 35 \text { ml of } 0.1 \text { NaOH } } \\ { 0.1 N \Rightarrow 1000 m l \text { of } 0.1 \text { mole } N a O H \text { is } 35 \text { ml } } \\ { = \cfrac { 35 \times 0.1 } { 1000 } = 0.35 \times 10 ^ { - 2 } } \\ { \text { Total } = 20 + 35 = 55 \mathrm { ml } } \end{array}\)

\(\begin{array} { l } { \Rightarrow ( 1.0 - 0.35 ) 10 ^ { - 2 } = 0.65 \times 10 ^ { - 2 } \text { mole } H C l } \\ { H C l = H ^ { + } + C l ^ { - } } \end{array}\)

\(\Rightarrow [ H C l ] = \left[ H _ { \omega } ^ { + } \right] + \left[ C l ^ { - } \right]\)

\(\begin{array} { l } { 55 \text { ml contains } 0.65 \times 10 ^ { - 2 } \text { mole of } H ^ { + } \text { ions } } \\ { 1000 \mathrm { ml } - \cfrac { 0.65 \times 10 ^ { - 2 } \times 10 ^ { 3 } } { 55 } = \cfrac { 6.5 } { 55 } } \\ { p H = - \log \left[ H ^ { + } \right] = - \log ( 6.5 / 55 ) } \\ { = \log 55 - \log 6.5 = 0.92 } \end{array}\)

Due to acidic nature of solutions the colour of phenolphthalein becomes pink.

\(2 \pi \mathrm{r} \cdot \mathrm{T}=\rho \mathrm{gh} \cdot \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{D}=2 \mathrm{r}=\cfrac{4 T}{\rho g h}\)

quest_title: A piece of glass is heated to a high temperature and then allowed to cool. If it cracks, a probable reason for this is the following property of glass
explanation_txt: When a piece of glass is cooled after being heated, due to low thermal conductivity it does not conduct heat throughout the body and non uniform cooling occurs. Hence unequal contraction of it’s layers crack the glass.
question_plain_title: A piece of glass is heated to a high temperature and then allowed to cool. If it cracks, a probable reason for this is the following property of glass
explanation_plain_text: When a piece of glass is cooled after being heated, due to low thermal conductivity it does not conduct heat throughout the body and non uniform cooling occurs. Hence unequal contraction of it’s layers crack the glass.

quest_title: Astronomical telescope having objective of focal length 60cm & eye lens of focal length 3cm is focused on moon. If the diameter of moon subtend an angle 0.5\({}^{o}\) at objective then size of image formed at least distance of distinct vision will be
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{m}=\cfrac{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{o}}}{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}}}\left(1+\cfrac{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}}}{\mathrm{D}}\right)=\cfrac{60}{3}\left(1+\cfrac{3}{25}\right)=22.4\)

Now,

\(\mathrm{m}=\cfrac{\beta}{\alpha}\)

\(\beta=22.4 \times 0.5=11.2^{\circ}\)

Now,

\(\beta=\cfrac{\mathrm{h}_{1}}{\mathrm{D}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{h}_{1}=11.2 \times \pi / 180 \times 25=4.9 \mathrm{cm}\)

ans1_txt: \(\oint _ { S } \left( \vec { E } _ { 1 } + \vec { E } _ { 2 } + \vec { E } _ { 3 } \right) \cdot d \vec { A } = \cfrac { q _ { 1 } + q _ { 2 } + q _ { 3 } } { 2 \varepsilon _ { 0 } }\)
ans2_txt: \(\oint _ { s } \left( \vec { E } _ { 1 } + \vec { E } _ { 2 } + \vec { E } _ { 3 } \right) \cdot d \vec { A } = \cfrac { \left( q _ { 1 } + q _ { 2 } + q _ { 3 } \right) } { \varepsilon _ { 0 } }\)

From Gauss law,

\(\int \vec { E } \cdot \vec { d A } = \cfrac { 1 } { \varepsilon _ { 0 } } \left( Q _ { e n c } \right)\)

quest_title: The equation of the bisectors of angle between the lines represented by equation \(( y - m x ) ^ { 2 } = ( x + m y ) ^ { 2 }\) is
explanation_txt:
The equation is

\(\begin{array} { l } { y ^ { 2 } + m ^ { 2 } x ^ { 2 } - 2 m x y - x ^ { 2 } - m ^ { 2 } y ^ { 2 } - 2 m x y = 0 } \\ { \Rightarrow x ^ { 2 } \left( m ^ { 2 } - 1 \right) + y ^ { 2 } \left( 1 - m ^ { 2 } \right) - 4 m x y = 0 } \end{array}\)

Therefore, the equation of bisectors is:

\(\cfrac { x ^ { 2 } - y ^ { 2 } } { x y } = \cfrac { \left( m ^ { 2 } - 1 \right) - \left( 1 - m ^ { 2 } \right) } { - 2 m } \Rightarrow m x ^ { 2 } + \left( m ^ { 2 } - 1 \right) x y - m y ^ { 2 } = 0 \)

explanation_plain_text:
The equation is

Therefore, the equation of bisectors is:

quest_title: 1.5 amp of current were passed through 400ml of 0.2M \(\text{ZnSO\(_{4}\)}\) solution for 10 mins. The concentration of solution after electrolysis is
explanation_txt:
The equation:

\(Z n^{2+}+2 e^{-} \rightarrow Z n\)

1 mole is deposited by : \(2 \times 96500 \mathrm{C}=193000 \mathrm{C}\)

charged supplied: 1.5 x 10 x 60 = 900 C

number of moles deposited by given charge = 900/193000 = 0.00466

moles in 400ml = .4 x .2 = .08

moles remaining in the 400 ml = 0.08 - 0.00466 = 0.07534 moles

 

Molarity = \(\cfrac{0.07534}{0.4} = 0.188 \approx 0.19M\)

quest_title: Increasing the temperature of an aqueous solution will cause;
explanation_txt: Temperature change causes increase in volume of solvent but the mass of the solvent remains the same. Among the four options, it is the only molarity which includes volume of solvent in its definition. Molarity of a solution is the ratio of number of moles of solute to the volume of solvent. When volume of solvent increases, molarity decreases.
question_plain_title: Increasing the temperature of an aqueous solution will cause;

Among the four options, it is the only molarity which includes volume of solvent in its definition. Molarity of a solution is the ratio of number of moles of solute to the volume of solvent. When volume of solvent increases, molarity decreases.

quest_title: If the sum of the squares of the distance of a point from the three co-ordinate axes be 36,then its distance from the origin is :
explanation_txt:
Let \(P\, (x,\, y,\, z).\) Now under given condition, we get;

\(\left[\sqrt{(x^{2} +y^{2} )} \right]^{2} +\left[\sqrt{(y^{2} +z^{2} )} \right]^{2} +\left[\sqrt{(z^{2} +x^{2} )} \right]^{2} =36\)

\(\Rightarrow \, \, x^{2} +y^{2} +z^{2} =18\)

Then distance from origin to the point is \[\sqrt{x^{2} +y^{2} +z^{2} } =\sqrt{18} =3\sqrt{2} .\]

NOTE: The distance of \( P(x,y,z) \) from \(z\) axis is \( \sqrt{x^2+y^2} \) and similar for others.

quest_title: A vessel contains a liquid of density 1.2g/cc over mercury of density 13.5g/cc. A homogenous sphere floats with one third in mercury and 2/3\({}^{rd}\) in liquid then density of sphere is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{wt}=\text { upthrust }} \\ {\mathrm{V} \rho \mathrm{g}=\cfrac{V}{3} \sigma_{m} g+\cfrac{2 V}{3} \sigma_{i} g} \\ {\therefore \rho=\cfrac{\sigma_{m}+2 \sigma_{i}}{3}=\cfrac{13.5+2 \times 1.2}{3}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: When a slow neutron is captured by a U\({}^{235}\)nucleus, a fission results which releases 200Mev energy. If the output of a nuclear reactor is 1.6Mw, what is the rate of nuclei undergoing fission?
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{P}=\cfrac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{t}} \times\) Energy per fission
or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{N}}{\mathrm{t}}=\cfrac{1.6 \times 10^{6}}{200 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-13}}=5 \times 10^{16}\)
